dialogs.original: [knocking]  My lord, my lord.
dialogs.translated: [Knocking] My lord, my lord.

dialogs.original: [within]  Who knocks?
dialogs.translated: [Offstage] Who's knocking?

dialogs.original: One from the Lord Stanley.
dialogs.translated: A messenger from Lord Stanley.

dialogs.original: [within]  What is t oclock?
dialogs.translated: [Offstage] What time is it?

dialogs.original: Upon the stroke of four.
dialogs.translated: Four in the morning.

dialogs.original: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?
dialogs.translated: Can't Lord Stanley sleep on this long night?

dialogs.original: So it appears by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble self.
dialogs.translated: It appears not, based on his message. First, he sends his regards to your noble self.

dialogs.original: What then?
dialogs.translated: And what else?

dialogs.original: Then certifies your Lordship that this night    He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm.    Besides, he says there are two councils kept,    And that may be determined at the one    Which may make you and him to rue at th' other.    Therefore he sends to know your Lordships pleasure,    If you will presently take horse with him    And with all speed post with him toward the north    To shun the danger that his soul divines.
dialogs.translated: He then tells your Lordship that tonight he dreamed that the boar cut off his head. He also says that there will be two council meetings tomorrow, and that the results of one meeting may make you and Stanleywho will be at the othervery sorry indeed. Because of this, he wants to know if you'll ride with him to the north as soon as possible, to escape the danger that his soul senses.

dialogs.original: Go, fellow, go. Return unto thy lord.    Bid him not fear the separated council.    His Honor and myself are at the one,    And at the other is my good friend Catesby,    Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us    Whereof I shall not have intelligence.    Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.    And for his dreams, I wonder hes so simple    To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers.    To fly the boar before the boar pursues    Were to incense the boar to follow us    And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.    Go, bid thy master rise and come to me,    And we will both together to the Tower,    Where he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.
dialogs.translated: Go, fellow, go. Return to your lord. Tell him not to worry about the two separate meetings. He and I will be at one meeting, and my good friend Catesby will be at the other. Nothing important can happen at the secret meeting without us hearing about it. Tell your lord that his fears are shadows without evidence. And as for his dreams, I'm surprised that he's so foolish as to trust the imaginings of restless sleep. To flee the boar before he even pursues us would make the boar angry, and incite him to chase us even if he never intended to in the first place. Go tell your master to get up and meet me, and we'll go together to the Tower. There he'll see that the boar will treat us kindly.

dialogs.original: Ill go, my lord, and tell him what you say.
dialogs.translated: I'll go and tell him what you say, my lord.

dialogs.original: Many good morrows to my noble lord.
dialogs.translated: Good morning to you, my noble lord.

dialogs.original: Good morrow, Catesby. You are early stirring.What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?
dialogs.translated: Good morning, Catesby. You're up early. What's the news in our unsteady kingdom?

dialogs.original: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord,And I believe will never stand uprightTill Richard wear the garland of the realm.
dialogs.translated: It is a crazy world indeed, my lord. And I believe it will never stand upright again until Richard wears the garland of the realm.

dialogs.original: How wear the garland? Dost thou mean the crown?
dialogs.translated: What do you mean, "wears the garland?" Do you mean the crown?

dialogs.original: Ay, my good lord.
dialogs.translated: Yes, my good lord.

dialogs.original: Ill have this crown of mine cut from my shouldersBefore Ill see the crown so foul misplaced.But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
dialogs.translated: I'll have my head cut from my shoulders before I'll see the crown so terribly misplaced. But do you think that's his intention?

dialogs.original: Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward    Upon his party for the gain thereof;    And thereupon he sends you this good news,    That this same very day your enemies,    The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.
dialogs.translated: Yes, I swear on my life. And he hopes that you'll join his side and help him. For that reason he sends you this good news: that this very day your enemiesthe queen's relativeswill die at Pomfret Castle.

dialogs.original: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,    Because they have been still my adversaries.    But that Ill give my voice on Richards side    To bar my masters heirs in true descent,    God knows I will not do it, to the death.
dialogs.translated: Indeed, I'm not sorry to hear that news, for they have always been my enemies. But as for the idea that I'd support Richard's side in keeping my master's true heirs from the throneGod knows I'll never do it. I'd rather die.

dialogs.original: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.
dialogs.translated: May God preserve your Lordship in that noble state of mind.

dialogs.original: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,    That they which brought me in my masters hate,    I live to look upon their tragedy.    Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older    Ill send some packing that yet think not on t.
dialogs.translated: But I'll laugh at all this in a year, and rejoice that I could see tragedy come to those who once convinced King Edward to hate me. Well, Catesby, before two weeks have passed I'll send some people packing who won't be expecting it at all.

dialogs.original: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.
dialogs.translated: It's a terrible thing to die when you're unprepared and not expecting it, my gracious lord.

dialogs.original: O monstrous, monstrous! And so falls it out    With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey;   and so twill do    With some men else that think themselves as safe    As thou and I, who, as thou knowst, are dear    To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
dialogs.translated: Yes, it's monstrous, monstrous! That's how it is for Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey. And that's how it will be soon for some other men who think they're as safe as you and I arewe who are dear to princely Richard and Buckingham.

dialogs.original: The princes both make high account of you  [aside]  For they account his head upon the Bridge.
dialogs.translated: Those two lords both think highly of you.

dialogs.original: I know they do, and I have well deserved it.
dialogs.translated: I know they do, and I deserve it.

dialogs.original: Come on, come on. Where is your boar-spear, man? Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
dialogs.translated: Come on, come on. Where is your boar-hunting spear, man? You're afraid of the boar, but you'll go around unarmed?

dialogs.original: My lord, good morrow. Good morrow, Catesby.You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood,I do not like these several councils, I.
dialogs.translated: My lord, good morning.

dialogs.original: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours,    And never in my days, I do protest,    Was it so precious to me as tis now.    Think you but that I know our state secure,    I would be so triumphant as I am?
dialogs.translated: My lord, I care about my life as much as you care about yours, and I swear I care about it as much now as I ever have. Do you think I would be as confident as I am if I wasn't certain of our safety?

dialogs.original: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,    Were jocund and supposed their states were sure,    And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;    But yet you see how soon the day o'ercast.    This sudden stab of rancor I misdoubt.    Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!    What, shall we toward the Tower? The day is spent.
dialogs.translated: When the queen's relatives rode from London, they too were joyful and felt sure that they were safe. And indeed they had no reason to worry. But see how quickly the day grew cloudy for themnow they're imprisoned at Pomfret Castle. Richard's sudden attack on them makes me worried. I pray to God that it turns out I'm being cowardly for no reason. Well, should we go to the Tower? The day has already begun.

dialogs.original: Come, come. Have with you. Wot you what, my lord?Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.
dialogs.translated: Come, come. Let's go. Do you know what, my lord? Those lords you just mentionedRivers and Greywill be beheaded today.

dialogs.original: They, for their truth, might better wear their headsThan some that have accused them wear their hats. But come, my lord, lets away.
dialogs.translated: To be honest, they deserve to keep their heads more than the people who've accused them deserve to keep their duke's caps. But come, my lord, let's go.

dialogs.original: Go on before. Ill talk with this good fellow.
dialogs.translated: Go on ahead. I'll talk with this good fellow.

dialogs.original: How now, sirrah! How goes the world with thee?
dialogs.translated: Hello, sir! How's the world treating you?

dialogs.original: The better that your Lordship please to ask.
dialogs.translated: Better, now that your Lordship was kind enough to ask.

dialogs.original: I tell thee, man, tis better with me now    Than when thou metst me last where now we meet.    Then was I going prisoner to the Tower    By the suggestion of the queens allies.    But now, I tell theekeep it to thyself    This day those enemies are put to death,    And I in better state than e'er I was.
dialogs.translated: I tell you, man, it's better with me now than it was the last time you met me here. At that time I was on my way to be imprisoned in the Tower, accused by the queen's allies. But now, I tell youand keep this to yourselfthose enemies are being put to death today, and I'm better than ever.

dialogs.original: God hold it, to your Honors good content!
dialogs.translated: May God preserve your good luck, your Honor!

dialogs.original: Gramercy, fellow. There, drink that for me.
dialogs.translated: Thank you very much, fellow. Here, have a drink on me.

dialogs.original: I thank your Honor.
dialogs.translated: I thank your Honor.

dialogs.original: Well met, my lord. I am glad to see your Honor.
dialogs.translated: Hello, my lord. I'm glad to see you.

dialogs.original: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.I am in your debt for your last exercise.Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.
dialogs.translated: I thank you with all my heart, Sir John. I'm in your debt for your last sermon. Next Sunday I'll give the church a nice donation.

dialogs.original: Ill wait upon your Lordship.
dialogs.translated: I'll come to see you, your Lordship.

dialogs.original: What, talking with a priest, Lord Chamberlain?Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
dialogs.translated: What, talking with a priest, Lord Hastings? Your friends at Pomfret Castle, they're the ones who need a priest. You, your Honor, have no deathbed confessions to make.

dialogs.original: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,The men you talk of came into my mind.What, go you toward the Tower?
dialogs.translated: Honestly, when I ran into this holy man, I did think of those men you mention. So, are you going to the Tower?

dialogs.original: I do, my lord, but long I shall not stay there. I shall return before your Lordship thence.
dialogs.translated: I am, my lord. But I won't stay there long. I'll return from there before your Lordship does.

dialogs.original: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.
dialogs.translated: That's likely, since I'm staying for lunch there.

dialogs.original: [aside]  And supper too, although thou knowst it not.Come, will you go?
dialogs.translated: [To himself] And for dinner too, though you don't know it yet.

dialogs.original: Ill wait upon your Lordship.
dialogs.translated: I'll follow your Lordship.
